Meeting Summary - 10th ASEAN+3 Bond Market Forum (ABMF) Meeting 
21-22 Nov 2012, Shangri-la Hotel, Bangkok, Thailand 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The 10th ASEAN+3 Bond Market Forum (ABMF) meeting was held on 21 and 22 Nov 
2012 in Bangkok, Thailand. The meeting was co-hosted by Thailand ABMF members (Thailand 
Bond Market Association (ThaiBMA), Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and The 
Stock Exchange of Thailand), Ministry of Finance, Thailand, Bank of Thailand and ADB. More 
than 140 national, regional, and global experts from the public and private sectors gathered at 
the meeting. The main purpose of the meeting was i) to discuss key characteristics of the 
proposed regionally standardized bond issuance program, Asian Multi-currency Bond Issuance 
Framework (AMBIF), and ii) review the identified bond transaction flows, preliminary findings of 
the fit and gap analysis, and policy recommendations to enhance STP in the region. The 
meeting agenda and participants list are in Attachments 1 and 2, respectively. 
2.  The regulatory bodies of ASEAN+3 were invited to the meeting to share in the key 
information on developing AMBIF.  It was the 2nd invitation following the 1st one to the Seoul 
ABMF meeting on 4 Sep 2012. In addition to their participation in the main ABMF meetings, the 
regulatory bodies had a separate session on 22 Nov 2012, from 16:30 to 18:30, to further 
discuss the details of AMBIF. Chaired by Asian Bond Market Initiative (ABMI) Task Force 3 
(TF3) chair and co-chair (Japan and Malaysia), regulatory bodies from 9 economies and ADB’s 
ABMF secretariat team (the secretariat) attended the session. 
3.  On the sideline of ABMF meetings, the 3rd ASEAN+3 Self Regulatory Organization (SRO) 
Working Group Meeting was held on 20 Nov 2012 hosted by ThaiBMA and PDS Holdings, 
Philippines. In the meeting, the SROs from seven economies exchanged information on the role 
and function of each organization and the views on feasible topics for future discussion. To 
further clarify the topics for future activities, they agreed to have a workshop, possibly on the 
sideline of the next ABMF meeting.  
4.  In addition, a signing ceremony was held for a coalition on information sharing among 
the  ThaiBMA,  Indonesian  Bond  Pricing  Agency,  and  Bond  Pricing  Agency  Malaysia.  The 
coalition among the three institutions was welcomed by ABMF members as an example of 
actual progress made in the region for more efficient information sharing, and some ABMF 
members participated in the event. (Details of the information sharing scheme are in Attachment 
3)    
II.  KEY DISCUSSION RESULTS (Meeting minutes will be provided later) 
(SF1: Discussion on AMBIF) 
5.  The secretariat (Prof. Inukai and Mr. Schmidt) presented a detailed concept of AMBIF 
including the basic approaches, key characteristics such as professional investor, professional 
markets, documentation, and issuers, and methodologies for actual implementation (Attachment 
4).  Through the presentation, it is highlighted that i) a “principle based” (PB) approach is 
recommended, meaning that specific details could be decided by the market participants based 
on mutually agreed core principles, ii) mutual recognition among the regulatory bodies are 
required on the key characteristics of AMBIF including normalization of approval process, iii)  
1

that a proxy approach is desired relative to approvals to create a key benefit for issuers, and iv) 
further discussion by the members is needed on the proposed key characteristics of AMBIF. 
Members appreciated the hard work done by the secretariat and discussed various points, 
including the following: 
•  A representative from  Korea Financial Investment Association (KOFIA) argued that PB 
approach alone might not be appropriate for Asia because of the institutional diversities of 
financial system in this region. Therefore, together with the PB approach, which basically 
follows the regulation style of the United Kingdom (UK), RB1 approach as in US regulations 
also needs to be considered for ASEAN + 3 countries to make appropriate regulatory 
choices according to each own financial situation. The secretariat opined that PB and RB 
approaches are not mutually exclusive because behind all the rules there are principles. The 
PB  approach  is  suggested  considering  that  it  could  make  regulatory  bodies  feel  more 
comfortable in their discussion for mutual recognition, but both approaches could be applied 
in future discussions, depending on the regulatory bodies’ comfort level. 
•  A representative from Tokyo Stock Exchange pointed out the need to clarify legal aspects of 
AMBIF for the purpose of consumer protection, to which the secretariat fully agreed and 
committed continued study. 
•  A  representative  from  People’s  Bank  of  China  opined  that  i)  AMBIF  could  influence 
macroeconomic  management  with  increased  cross  border  capital  flows  and  such 
macroeconomic aspects should be reviewed, ii) the key concepts such as investors, eligible 
bonds should be clearly defined, and iii) some information on the Chinese market should be 
revised. The secretariat agreed on the points, and added that AMBIF could contribute to 
more balanced growth and stable macroeconomic environment by deepening local currency 
bond markets, although the AMBIF discussion is not directly related to macroeconomic 
issues.    ABMF  will  be  ready  to  address  macroeconomic  concern  of  ASEAN+3  policy 
authorities, if any specific advice is given.     
•  One international expert raised question on how to build the supply side of AMBIF, including 
the channeling of key information to potential issuers. The secretariat replied that market 
associations and SROs are assumed to perform a key role in distributing AMBIF information 
to the market.  
•  Several  participants,  including  the  Assistant  Governor  of  the  Bank  of  Thailand,  raised 
questions  and  added  comments  on  the  approaches,  concepts  and  targeted  outputs  of 
AMBIF. In sum, the secretariat explained that AMBIF is aiming to make it possible for bond 
issuers to issue bonds in any participation locations (without requiring physical presence) 
with  one  standardized  documentation,  and  for  mutually  agreed  professional  investors 
(AMBIF  investors)  to  sell  and  buy  the  issued  bonds  without  selling  restrictions  among 
themselves. To achieve the goal, mutual recognition is proposed in either a multilateral or 
multiple of bilateral format, using a step-by-step approach. As for the question raised by a 
representative from the Malaysian Investment Banking Association on whether AMBIF will 
allow foreign currency denominated bond issuance by non-residents, the secretariat clarified 
that this would be determined by regulatory bodies in each economy.       
                                                 
1 It is generally understood that a "rule-based approach" is the way that sets detailed binding parameters to be 
applied to individual cases, requiring participants in a market must operate within the parameters. On the other 
hand, a “principle base approach” means the way that encourages voluntary efforts of the market participants to 
operate within generally agreed principles; such principles are typically applied in more generic terms than specific 
rules 
 
2

•  The secretariat expressed sincere appreciation to members for their support in preparing 
AMBIF proposal and additional comments during the meeting. Based on the points raised by 
the members, the secretariat will further refine the concept of AMBIF and report it to the next 
ABMF meeting.  
6.  In relation to the AMBIF discussion, there were information sharing sessions on i) the 
methods for mutual recognition, and ii) the experience of ASEAN Capital Market Forum (ACMF):  
Representatives from ASIFMA presented to the members the concept of ‘mutual recognition’   
and ‘mutual agreement’ - the former requires changes in regulation while the latter could be 
achieved without changes in regulation - together with specific experiences in both concepts. It 
is understood that AMBIF will require mutual recognition on key characteristics, although mutual 
agreement on the sideline issues could add benefits to AMBIF. A representative from Thailand 
SEC presented the progress in ACMF focusing on bond market harmonization.  It is shared with 
the members that AMBIF is different from ACMF initiatives in that i) ACMF does not directly 
focus  on  professional  investors,  and  ii)  mutual  recognition  on  the  concept  of  professional 
investors and documentation is not included in ACMF.  
 (SF2: Identification of bond transaction flows) 
7.  The secretariat (Dr. Inui and Mr. Kawai) presented to the members i) updated DVP flows 
of corporate bonds, and the flows for interest payment and redemption of each economy, ii) 
preliminary findings of the fit and gap (F&G) analysis on the transaction flows and message 
items, and ii) draft policy recommendations to enhance STP in the region. 
8.  Some of the National Members (NMs) including those from PRC, Thailand, Indonesia, 
and Malaysia provided additional comments on the presented information and flow diagrams for 
their respective economies and some International Experts (IEs) also offered feedback. The 
secretariat expressed sincere thanks for the support from the members in identifying the flows 
and additional comments. All the comments were well noted by the secretariat and would be 
reflected appropriately. 
9.  It was the first time that preliminary findings of the F&G analysis were shared with the 
members, and the secretariat requested careful review of the details of the findings, which will 
be the basis for policy recommendations. One IE pointed out that the F&G analysis on message 
items utilizing only 10 common elements for a settlement instruction is not enough to see the 
whole process. The secretariat explained that the current analysis, which is focusing only on 10 
elements due to resource limitation, is to check what can be found through the analysis and it 
could be expanded in the future to include more items. 
10.   As for policy recommendations and roadmap, various points have been actively raised 
by many IEs and some NMs, including the following: 
•  The secretariat proposed to include discussion on CCP as one policy recommendation. An 
IE (from Clearstream) opined that it should be decided through further discussion under 
current situation in the region where most economies are not yet having a CCP in bond 
transactions, although recent regulation changes such as Basel III and the Dobb-Frank Act 
require serious consideration of it. Another IE (from J.P. Morgan) sought clarification of the 
concept of CCP, whether just as a central point of trade capture, trade reporting and net 
calculation of positions for settlement or as a central counterparty assuming the credit risk of 
3

trading parties. If the latter, he added that the industry had strong reservations since there 
are additional risk and liquidity considerations to be made in that regard. 
•  The study on cross-border collateral (CBC), which was suggested as one of the policy 
recommendations, has been heavily discussed among the members. In general, most of the 
members  agreed  on  the  importance  of  the  issue  of  CBC.  Members  from  Japan  and 
Clearstream  argued  that  a  priority  might  be  given  to  CBC  rather  than  other  policy 
recommendations. A NM from Hong Kong introduced on-going efforts to enhance CBC. An 
IE from The Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ mentioned bilateral efforts for CBC by Bank of 
Japan and Bank of Thailand and pointed out there is a need for further improvement 
including the shortening timing for getting liquidity, which currently requires 7 days. The 
secretariat agreed on the potential importance of CBC as future agenda of ABMF, and 
added that several options and models for CBC could be explored on a non-obligation basis, 
subject to the members’ discussion.   
•  Other comments were also provided including re-organizing the policy recommendations 
with priorities, revising inaccurate descriptions to avoid unnecessary confusion, and utilizing 
national market practice groups (NMPG) for the standardizing of transaction flows. The 
secretariat thanked all the members for the valuable comments, requested continued review 
on the key findings of SF2 materials, and committed to refining the recommendations for the 
discussion during the next ABMF meeting.  
 
11.  In relation to the SF2 discussion, information on the Regional Settlement Intermediary 
(RSI) has been shared through a presentation by an ADB consultant for the RSI study.  He 
explained to the members about a new business feasibility study on RSI which is currently in 
progress and would be finalized by the end of this year.  
(Other issues) 
12.  The secretariat reported to members i) the result of the ABMI TF3 meeting in Kunming 
on 17 Oct 2012, ii) progress in knowledge support for Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Lao PDR, 
Myanmar, and Vietnam, and iii) on the ABMF public conference at Sibos on 31 Oct 2012. A plan 
for updating Phase 1 reports was also introduced to members by SWIFT, acting as secretariat 
of the ad-hoc updating team.   
13.  The work plan after the meeting has been shared with the members as in Table 1. The 
next ABMF meeting will be held in Singapore on 5-6 February 2013. Key components of AMBIF 
and draft policy recommendations to enhance STP will be further refined and presented by the 
secretariat for members’ discussion. 
14.  Mr. Shunzo Kayanuma from Tokyo Stock Exchange took over the chairmanship of SF1 
from Mr. Tetsutaro Muraki and chaired the SF1 meeting on 21 Nov 2012.   
15.  All presentation materials during the meeting have been made available at the Members 
Library section of the ABMF website (http://asean3abmf.adb.org). 
 
 
 
 
4

Table 1: Work Plan after Seoul meeting 
21-22 Nov 2012  10th ABMF Meeting in Bangkok 
6-7 Dec 2012  BCLM Knowledge support - kick-off seminar 
5-6 Feb 2013  11th ABMF meeting in Singapore 
Q1~Q2 2013  BCLM knowledge support – market visits 
Mar 2013  ABMI TF3 meeting (4th reporting of Phase 2) 
Apr 2013  12th ABMF meeting 
Apr 2013  Submitting the report to ASEAN+3 Deputies meeting 
May 2013  Recommendations approved by ASEAN+3 Ministers 
Q2~ 2013  BCLM knowledge support – additional support/follow-up 
Following up on the implementation of recommendations 
Finalize Phase 2 full report 
2nd Half 2013 
Pilot issue (tentative)

2-2-6. Benefits of ‘AMBIF Markets’
• Simply chose from existing markets or segments
• No need to create a specific market or segment
• Decision making (control) by crucial constituents
• Basically, no need to amend existing, or pass 
additional legislation
• No need to officially integrate markets across 
jurisdictions
• While retaining opportunities to create a common 
market at a later stage

Market Visit Summary: Malaysia
Key Findings
• Professional (Sophisticated investors qualify issue) market segment: “Excluded 
Offers”; no use of term ‘private placement’ in regulations and guidelines.
• RReeffeerrss ttoo ooffffeerrss ttoo 1133 ttyyppeess ooff iinnvveessttoorrss ssppeecciiffiieedd iinn SScchheedduulleess 66 aanndd 77 ooff CCaappiittaall 
Market and Securities Act (CMSA), where issuance is exempted from prospectus.
• Certain foreign persons (individual and corporation in Schedule 6 and 7 of CMSA) are 
regarded as Sophisticated Investors.
• But, typically requires depositing documentation (Information Memorandum) with SC 
Malaysia, and approval.
• Selling restrictions to be included in documentation.
• There is a plan by SC Malaysia to soon specify sophisticated investors to include (1) 
high net-worth individuals, (2) high net-worth entities and (3) accredited investors.
Issue identified
• Usage of the word of ‘Principal Advisor’ is, relative to other intermediaries, different 
from other markets. The corporate finance adviser is responsible for making 
submissions to the SC Malaysia for corporate proposals. This is unique in Malaysia 
given the due diligence requirements on all proposals submitted to the SC.

Market Visit Summary: Viet Nam

• First instance of recognition of ‘professional investors’ concept in Securities

• Poor continuous disclosure observed by market
• Actual availability of securities for sale following an auction

Key Findings (tentative draft)
1. Bond Market
(cid:190) Most of bonds (both government and corporate bonds) are traded in OTC markets 
in ASEAN+3 (where bond market exist).
(cid:190) Significant volume of bonds are traded in exchange (order driven) market only in 
KR and PH.
(cid:190) Regarding bond trades, most of the trades are ordered and executed domestically.
(cid:190) Post-trade matching systems and/or data collection systems are not always 
connected with pre-settlement matching system and/or CSD systems.
2. Central Counter-Party
(cid:190) CCPs (Central Counter-Parties) have been established in only a few economies 
(CN, JP, and KR) for bond trades. 
3. Pre-settlement and settlement Matching
(cid:190) In many markets, pre-settlement matching is conducted manually using telephone, 
facsimile, e-mail, etc. 
(cid:190) Both central matching and local matching are used as settlement matching for 
both government and corporate bonds. 
12
Key Findings (tentative draft)
4. Bond settlement
(cid:190) Regarding government bonds, central bank related CSDs mostly settle them in 6 
markets (CN, HK, ID, JP, MY, and SG)  out of 10 major markets in ASEAN+3.  
Exchange related CSDs mostly settle them in 3 markets (KR, TH, and VN).  
Government  related CSD manly settles and exchange related CSD settles 
siigniiffiicantt porttiion off tthhem as subb-regiisttry iin one markkett ((PPHH)). 
(cid:190) Regarding corporate bonds, central bank related CSDs mostly settle them in 2 
markets (HK and MY)  out of 10 major markets in ASEAN+3.  Exchange related 
CSDs mostly settle them in 7 markets (ID, JP, KR, PH, SG, TH, and VN).  Central 
bank  related CSDs and exchange related CSD settle them in one market (CN). 
Significant percentage of bonds remains as physical certificates.
5. Cash settlement
(cid:190) Regarding government bonds, central bank money is used in all markets except in 
VN in ASEAN+3.  DVP model 1 of BIS definition is available in these 9 markets. 
Commercial bank money can also be used in CN though the percentage to total 
settlement value is very low.
(cid:190) Regarding corporate bonds, central bank money is used in 8 markets (CN, HK, JP, 
KR, MY, PH, SG, and TH) .  Commercial bank money is used in 3 markets (CN, ID, 
and VN).  In CN, central bank money is mainly used but commercial bank money 
is used when bonds are settled in exchange related CSD.

Summary of interest payment process of government 
bond for reference
1. When issuers pay interest to investors, paying agents(PA), which are 
designated by issuers, transfer money to the accounts of account management 
agents (AMA)s which are appointed by investors.

bond holders. From the view point of no-residents’ transaction, custodians play 
a role as AMA.

Numbering and coding
(cid:190) ISIN (International Securities Identification Number) is not used in many 
economies.  Also, numbering convention of ISIN is not standardized, yet.
(cid:190) BIC is not used in many economies, yet in stead, local proprietary codes 
aarree uusseedd.
(cid:190) Securities account structure is proprietary one in all economies in 
ASEAN+3.
Others (including from Phase 1 results)
(cid:190) Settlement cycle is not regarded as a rule of each market.
(cid:190) Physical certificate remains in many markets in particular for corporate 
bonds.
(cid:190) Cost of cross-border transactions in ASEAN+3 is said to be much higher 
than that of other region since post-trade (clearing and settlement) 
infrastructures in ASEAN+3 are fragmented like silo.

4.1.1 FMI Related Recommendations
1. Cross-border STP Survey to include Trading Systems
Regarding trading systems, further survey may better be done from the 
view point of cross-border STP since ABMF survey during phase 1 and

2. Development of Pre-settlement matching Infrastructures
Such matching infrastructures are not  yet developed in ASEAN+3.

4.1.1 FMI Related Recommendations
3. Discussion on CCP
Transaction volume and value of bond trade and settlement in ASEAN+3 are 
not very large nor high for the time being.  However, it is anticipated that the 
bond transaction volume (and value as well) increase drastically. Therefore, it 
may be helpful to start discussion on CCP about under what kind of 
conditions and circumstances a CCP needs to be implemented. Counterparty 
risk may also be reduced by novation of CCP.
4. Involvement of Central Banks 
Since many of CSD and RTGS systems are owned and operated by central 
banks, it may be advisable for relevant departments such as payment system

4.1.4 Cross-border DVP related Recommendations
1. Enhancing Local Currency Availability and Liquidity
Except Hong Kong, Japan and Singapore, there remain some FX and 
cash controls for bond trade and DVP settlement in ASEAN+3. Obtaining, 
maintaining and divesting local currency balances is critical to non-
resiiddentt iinvesttors, ffor tthhe purpose off cross-bbordder bbondd iinvesttmentts. 
Some impact from FX and funding requirement limitations influence timing 
and cost of transaction processing. Since regulations concerning FX and 
cash controls aim not for bond trade but for other reasons, it may be 
difficult and inappropriate to abolish or change the regulations. Thus, it will 
be meaningful to discuss some measures such as cross-border collateral 
to enhance LCY (local currency) availability and liquidity for non-residents

4.1.5 Interest Payment Flow Related Recommendations
1. Discussion of the Roles of PA, AMA, and TWA
In the process of interest payment from issuers to investors, paying 
agents (PA)  which are designated by issuers, transfer interests to 
account management agents (AMA). In general, tax withholding 
agents(TWA) pay tax for bond holders to tax office. Central banks, 
commercial banks, CSDs and Bureau of Treasury, act as TWA. The 
basic roles of PA, AMA, TWA need to be clarified to find out the 
common matters and gaps in order to make cross-border interest 
payment more efficiently. 
2. Standardization of Interest Payment Flow
Interest payment flows are different market by market or even CSD by 
CSD, standardization of flows  is to be discussed.

4.1.6 Numbering and Coding Related Recommendations
1. Common Rules on ISIN
Common rules will be needed about numbering and notification of ISIN. 
For instance, after receiving bond information, a CSD numbers ISIN 
assigned by numbering agency and notifies trustees and CSD 
parttiiciipantts on tthhe same dday.
2. Promotion of BIC
Some market infrastructures still use proprietary code for financial 
institution identification. BIC will be adopted taking the opportunity of re-
construction of their systems. In addition, it is desirable that each 
economy has common recognition about numbering , notification and 
maintenance of BIC.
33. DDiiscussiion on IInvesttor IIddenttiiffiicattiion
It is important to ensure the uniqueness of identification of investors in 
cross-border transaction (relating to LEI).
(cid:190) Each economy should have the methods that each investor has unique ID 
and market infrastructures disclose it timely and clearly. If an economy has 
the method, it must be recognized by other economies and ASEAN+3 
economies may try to harmonize and standardize the method.

4.1.7 Business Practice Related Recommendations
1. Market Practice
- Cut off time, fail rule and settlement cycle will be discussed for the purpose 
of common recognition and harmonization. SROs may lead the discussion.
22. AAccountt SSttructture
- Due to differences of a bond holder’s right to claims on assets, there are 
some types of account: own account, customer account, pledge account, 
trustee account and so on. In addition, taxation has influences on account 
structures: non-taxable account and taxable account. In consideration of the 
above, it is desirable to discus the standardization of account structures. 
Entitlement may also be discussed.  
3. Language and code scheme for bond settlement infrastructures
- English may or may not be available for all cross-border transaction. 
- Latest materials about Regulations concerning Bond Book-Entry System 
may be shared in English.
